utterances: And in some ways, that's good.
You can't blame them - you can't blame these business owners for being gun shy.
They don't want to, you know, take on people who they can't afford to have on staff.

But it's tough because, you know, you wonder what will happen, especially with work like (unintelligible) when people are just working around the clock and not, you know, getting paid, you know, 1991 levels, as the caller the said.
Heather, we wish you the best of luck.
Thanks very much for the call.
And we'd also like to thank Colleen DeBaise of the Wall Street Journal, the small business editor there who joined us from our bureau in New York.
She's the author of ""The Wall Street Journal Complete Small Business Guidebook."" Thanks very much for your time today.
Oh, my pleasure.
As mentioned, today, President-elect Obama reinvigorated the call echoed by so many over the years to celebrate the holiday to honor Mark Luther King, Jr. as a national day of service.

This morning, the president-elect visited wounded soldiers at Walter Reed Army Medical Center here in Washington and helped paint a wall in a local homeless shelter like many people in many communities around the country.
Michelle Obama put together care packages for troops overseas while many others refurbished schools, cleaned up neighborhoods, and provided food to the homeless and the hungry.
How did you mark this Martin Luther King Day?
Our phone number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org and join the conversation on our Web site, npr.org.
Just click on Talk of the Nation.
Jean Wilson joins us now by phone from Detroit, where she is executive director of United Peace Relief Detroit.
Nice to have you on Talk of the Nation today.
Hello, Neal.
It's good to see you - I mean good to talk to you here.
And what have you been doing today?
Well, today, I got up and made a huge pot of chili, and about 20 people came over.
At first, I thought oh, there's not that much for 20 people to do, but there really was.

And we prepared meals for about 250 people and brought some and put them in our cars and everything and brought them down to the local neighborhood service organization, which houses up to as many people that can fit in there, which was really packed today, cold day.
And we fed right outside, and there were line - it was like a long line of people.
We also had clothing to give away, socks, mittens, things like that.
That you've been collecting, I supposed, for some time.
Yes.

Well, I do collect constantly, and people give me things because I do put on soup kitchens either by myself - I'd actually - I had put on soup kitchens, a few of them with just myself using homeless people helping me put it on.
I show up with the food and say, OK, now, we're going to serve, you know, each other.
We're going to be good about this, and it's really, really great.
And today, there was such an overwhelming response to Obama's call to come out and serve.
I had so many phone calls that I said, let's do it today.
So today, we were able to do it real nice and big, and it was actually a lot of fun, and, you know, it was very good for all.
We had a very nice experience.
And it's important to do it on - well, there's always plenty of volunteers, I think, on Martin Luther King Day, on Thanksgiving, on Christmas, too.
Yes.
This research suggests, you know, at least on social media, half your budget might not just be wasted, it might be cannibalizing what the other half is doing.
You know, at this point, we only have one has scheduled a trip to South Dakota and we are pleased that we've got even that many considering where we're at in the schedule.
Well, you know, where you are in the schedule.
The question arise is why even bother?
State Sec.

NELSON: Well, South Dakota obviously wants to be part of the nomination process, and as we have looked at the frontloading of that process, we've determined that it really isn't going to be feasible for us to try to move our primary into that front section.
In 1988, South Dakota did move our primary into February and we were one of the very first states in the country.
We had a lot of the candidates coming through South Dakota, it was a very effective time for us.
We got to meet the candidates and they got to understand our issues in South Dakota.

But that worked once and we kept that early primary in '92 and '96 but as more and more of the larger states begin moving forward, essentially, South Dakota lost the bang for the buck and the candidates were going to the other larger states.

And so in a move of physical prudence, our legislature decided we're going to move the presidential primary back to June, recombine it with our state primary so we're not paying for two different elections.
Yeah.
Well, since you've done that, do people really ever come to campaign?
Because by June, it's really over, isn't it?
State Sec.

NELSON: Well, by June, it's really over and my prognostication is that it may well be over by the first week of February this year and so it's doubtful that we'll get much exposure at all, although I do point out there's always that one in a million chance that things won't be locked up and things could get rather exciting in South Dakota, being the last one on the block.
The phrase the lonely plane is probably overdone but I'm not sure you're doing anything to help here.
State Sec.
NELSON: Well, that's true.

We're pragmatic about it, we understand that because we're not one of the larger states even if we did move up in that process, we're still not going to get the focus of the other states are and so we've taken a pragmatic approach.
We're going to be in June and live with that.

My great hope as secretary of state is that the country will understand that this frontloaded process is broken and hopefully, we can move to some type of a rotating regional process whereby each of the states has an opportunity to be in that front spot.
Chris Nelson, secretary of state in South Dakota, which is worth seeing on its own without a lot of electioneering folderol.
State Sec.
NELSON: You put that very well.
Thank you, Alex.
Thanks, Chris.
President Trump enjoyed pomp and pageantry as he closed out his visit here in England.
But the day was dominated by controversy, beginning with negative remarks the president made to the British tabloid the Sun about prime minister Theresa May.
Meanwhile, back in Washington, the Justice Department announced indictments against 12 Russian intelligence officers for interference in the 2016 election.
Now, this comes just days before Trump is due to meet with Russian president Vladimir Putin in Finland.
NPR White House reporter Ayesha Rascoe has been traveling with the president, and she joins me now.
Hey there, Ayesha.
Hello, Mary Louise.
So what is the White House reaction to the news of these 12 Russians being indicted?
The White House is pointing out that there is no allegation that - in this indictment that any Americans committed a crime or knew they were communicating with the Russians.
And they're also pointing out that the indictment doesn't say that there - that this conspiracy changed the vote count or affected the election results.
What's striking, though, is that the White House statement does not call out Russia or take them to task over these allegations.
President Trump held a news conference with prime minister Theresa May here in the U.K., as you know, before these indictments were announced.
He was still talking about the Russian probe as a rigged witch hunt.
And he got asked about this upcoming summit with Putin.
What exactly did he have to say?
We know now that Trump had actually been briefed on these indictments before he went on this trip.
So he knew about them when he was talking about - talking at the press conference.
Trump said he plans to talk with Putin about Russian interference in the 2016 election.
Here's what he said.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I know you'll ask what will we be talking about - meddling?
And I will absolutely bring that up.
I don't think you'll have any, gee, I did it.
I did it.
You got me.
There won't be a Perry Mason here, I don't think.
But you never know what happens, right?
It's not clear that Trump will press Putin more now that these indictments have come out.
Trump did defend his record with Putin.
He said that he's been pressing NATO to spend more, and they are.
And that's bad for Russia.

Let me turn you to another matter, which is another thing that came up at this press conference today with Trump and Theresa May - those comments he made to the Sun in which he said May should have taken his advice on how to handle Brexit, that she didn't and that therefore a trade deal with the U.K.
might be off.
But then this kind of turned around at the press conference.
What happened?
So he denied that he criticized her.
He said he made very positive comments about May that weren't highlighted.
But he is on tape saying these things.
He did say that he - that the U.S.
is willing to make a trade deal with the U.K.
and that basically U.K.
just needs to work out Brexit on their own and that, as long as the U.S.
can trade with the U.K., that's fine with him.
NPR's Ayesha Rascoe, traveling with the president.
Thanks.
Thank you.
It's Tuesday, the day we read from your emails and Web comments.
We focused last week on the reality and the perceptions of growing up Latino in the United States.
A new report showed high rates of teen pregnancy, gang affiliation and school dropouts.
But it also found that the majority of Latino youth speak English as their dominant language, place a high value on education and career success.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
But it was interesting to hear the president-elect to say, look, no hands - I think I'm paraphrasing here - no hands can be idle in this crisis.
We need to renew our commitment to service.
Government can't do it by itself.
We can't just do this one day a year.
Right, right.
I mean, it's a good move to do that today.
I've never seen so many people come out on Martin Luther King Day.
I mean, never before have we had a president that says, we're going to do this today.
This is what we're going to do.
No hands will be idle.
And I really love to hear Obama talking about that we all should volunteer and pull up our shirt sleeves, and that's what I've been saying, too.
And now, it's time to get to work.
But how do you sustain that commitment?
How do you sustain that commitment?
There are a lot of people and lots of resources.
Like, for instance, today, I didn't have the food I needed.
I didn't have what I needed, but I put a call out there for volunteers and stuff, and people came and brought cups and those ingredients for the food.
I mean, everything, we just made it all happen ourselves.
And how do you then get those people who were doing it today to come back next week and the week after?
Well, right now, a bunch of us has met up with the local restaurant, Cast(ph) Cafe, and we were discussing that.

And there are some people who do want to continue to do things, and there are some people who occasionally call and come and help out, and there was a few people who have for the very first time, and they think they'd like to do it again.
And what are you going to be doing tomorrow?
